Are you actually talking about Mike Wallace of the Univ. of Washington or someone else? Have you read his c.v. and/or bibliography (with awards including the Rossby Award, 1993, and Revelle Medal, 1999)?

This piece is about climate, not views on energy policy. What in the world do you see in Dr. Wallace's climate work that disqualifies him from weighing in along with Dr. Hansen?

If you want to include energy views, then I assume that means you endorse Jim Hansen's push for nuclear and recent criticism of environmentalists pushing solar and wind?

replies.commentBody: Your focus on edges leads you (and many) to confuse the sometimes-real "false middle" with the real middle in dealing with challenging science.

comments.commentBody:
This Dr. Wallace (yes, I had the name but not the person confused) seems unexceptionable, but like many others his "balance" represents the "false middle".

Dr. Wallace’s positions on energy exploration include extreme fossil fuels. He appears to my admittedly critical eye to belittle the accelerating emergency we face and the level of understanding we have about its causes.

"John Michael Wallace is a professor of Atmospheric Sciences at the University of Washington, as well as the former director of the Joint Institute for the Study of the Atmosphere and Ocean (JISAO)–a joint research venture between the University of Washington and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). His research concerns understanding global climate and its variations using observations and covers the quasi biennial oscillation, Pacific decadal oscillation and the annular modes of the Arctic oscillation and the Antarctic oscillation, and the dominant spatial patterns in month-to-month and year-to-year climate variability, including the one through which El Niño phenomenon in the tropical Pacific influences climate over North America. He is also the coauthor with Peter V. Hobbs of what is generally considered the standard introductory textbook in the field: Atmospheric Science: An Introductory Survey. He was the third most cited geoscientist during the period 1973-2007."

His textbook, written in 1977 and revised in 2006, is said to be one of the best on meteorology around.

comments.commentBody:
Fascinating. Andy Revkin links to Dr. Pielke Jr. (2007) as the "real" middle. I seem to remember him calling out Eli Rabett for noting his influence here.

The real middle is that presented in peer reviewed science, published in major scientific publications, the IPCC (which is on the whole a conservative summary of the state of knowledge at the time of publication, and outpaced by events), the position of every major organization worldwide that is qualified to study the many aspects of climate science, and on and on. The NYTimes section on global warming like most major news sources is informative.

The argument here enables a lot of disinformation.

As to nuclear, I avoid talking about it because discussion generates more heat than light. It trades long-term toxicity for clear and present danger, but I know and respect a lot of people who are for it. I was particularly interested in the pebble technology described in Al Gore's Choices book.

I do believe that extreme fuels are going to tip us over the edge in the next few decades; no need to wait for 2050. They are wasteful and their toxicity is not limited to greenhouse gases. The kind of thinking to pushes out billions to the most profitable fossil fuel enterprises and does a witchhunt on Solyndra is sending us all over the edge. (One can't help but think of major oil spiles and waste). If fossil fuels were priced realistically compared to other energy sources and methods of delivery, we could all get on.

Here we have Dr. Hansen, who knows what he is talking about, one of the climate science giants of our time juxtaposed with one of the apologists du jour for business as usual, including extreme fuels with all their concomitant toxicity, overuse and poisoning of water, earthquakes, and the lot. While the North Sea bubbles from another toxic spill and weather provides some startling evidence of what has been predicted since the 1970s, stonewalling has become fashionable.

Politics has silenced the conversation we should be having, but that does not mean that earth is not providing plentiful evidence that more energy and increased water vapor are providing a rich stew for every kind of change.

Seems prolonging the argument has become an obsession with the "middle" - and all in the name of blaming the argument for our problems. Go figure!

While many of Douthat's observations are correct and interesting to keep in mind (the historical context of presidential candidates' religions), his conclusions are troubling and fall into the familiar trap of false equivalencies between left and right in an attempt to claim neutrality. The left's trouble with Rick Santorum or any of the recent extreme anti-abortion, anti-birth control actions of conservative religious politicians is not "perfervid paranoia" about a "looming evangelical-led theocracy." The left is fighting against these ideas because the ideas are wrong, and because oppression and intolerance cloaked in religion is still oppression and intolerance. Moreover, harkening back to a mythical time when the (now-fractured) "moral authority" of religion helped unite a nation to achieve civil rights is overly simplistic and ignores the long history of religious racial intolerance in America. (Look up some religious arguments against miscegenation if you want to get deja vu with today's anti-same-sex-marriage crusaders). Either way, it is American religion that has turned away from civil rights, not the left who has abandoned religion. Ultimately this article's entire point seems to be the same as most conservative religious politicians: vaguely decry the disintegration of our nation's moral center, gaze longingly at an invented past, argue (apparently?) for a greater influence of religion in secular life? And what form, praytell, should that take?

comments.commentBody: The damage from Irene did not come from the storm intensity.  The damage came came when Irene had moved inland and diminished back to tropical storm strength but dropped torrential rain on the northeast causing heavy flooding in Vermont and upstate New York.  A week later upstate New York experienced the same scenario from Tropical Storm Lee.  Increased precipitation from tropical cyclones is one of the predicted impacts of global warming.

All nonsense. I'd say the most damaging (in the sense of self-defeating) AGW strategy is the attempt to tie Co2 to "extreme events."
Do you suppose you're winning friends and influencing people when Bill McKibben says of last years t.s...."Irene has a middle name and the name is global warming" without a shred of evidence. In fact, hurricane intensity and frequency has declined, not risen.
Meanwhile, tornadic activity is caused chiefly by cooling, not warming. I could go on, but why bother?

15 years of no warming, with many more to come. But why let a little thing like actual data get in the way?
